content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very funny problem. Difficulty level is just right.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good to me :D
Agry with alchemsti, I worry a little bit 5 minutes might not be enough to solve it though. But task is interesting.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really like this problem

I like the problem from the algorithm side. (I assume min of days provided by each clothing type). I'm not as keen on the amount of string parsing needed. I'm likely biased by using mainly C++.

If different names were used
Sock
Jeans
T-Shirt
Hoody / Pullover 
it would be easier.

That said, I guess it's not too bad as it is.

I worry a little bit 5 minutes might not be enough to solve it though.

I think it'd be a bit more interesting, if you could wear different articles of clothing for differing amounts of days, for example jeans could easily last you 3 days without getting noticably dirty in the process

I like the problem, but have the following comments:

I think you need to add a "wearing only items from the list provided" clause.

You don't specify that each item of clothing can only be worn on one day (understandable for socks, but it wouldn't be unreasonable to wear a sweater for more than one day).

I wasn't sure if I was going to have to code for *matching* socks. "2 SOCKs (they don't have to be the same colour)" might help.
[Alternatively, changing the requirement to "socks must match" could make this more challenging]

To those more experienced: is the last constraint written correctly? The idea is that the line will contain only one of the four keywords, but the keyword itself may be repeated multiple times. For example, "sock sock sock" will count as a single SOCK, but "sock shirt" is an illegal input.

Thanks, I added some clarification to the second paragraph of the statement and the output. I thought that matching socks would be annoying to implement in shortest mode and thus less fun, so I had decided not to include it. If people think the problem is too easy, I can add it in.

It's not much difference than implementing the original problem, so I think this is a fair addition, especially since we have two votes for it now. I put in some arbitrary numbers for the various articles of clothing. Personally I do laundry like a slob so I imagine there will be some people who will look at the numbers with a raised eyebrow :D.

Something that might simplify it a bit is providing guarantees on the input -- e.g. always two words, always the same form for clothing items, e.g Capitalized.

For a Code Clash I don't think the excessive input verification is worthwhile.

I don't quite understand your worries. Is C++ not easily capable of converting a string to lowercase and then searching for if it contains another string (see my solution)? The input strings are more-or-less freeform since ever language I've seen has a string contains() of some sort.

I'm also not sure how changing the names of the classes makes a difference.

Thanks!
